elements.title: Progressive Micro-Commitment Chain with Reciprocal Value
elements.problem: Guests make escalating commitments (bid submission, call participation, providing detailed requirements) but receive diminishing tangible value in return. The Zella call demonstrates this asymmetry: she provided location details (CCNY area, 125th-145th St, St. Nicholas Park proximity), schedule requirements (Wednesday-Saturday), timeline (7/20 check-in), and budget information, but received zero concrete listings, no confirmed availability, and only a vague promise that matching would take 'a couple of weeks.' Cialdini's commitment research shows that small initial commitments create consistency pressure to continue, but when those commitments aren't reciprocated with equivalent value, the consistency pressure weakens and dropout becomes likely. The guest invested call time and information but left empty-handed.
elements.solution: Design each commitment step to provide immediate reciprocal value that validates the guest's investment and creates momentum for the next step. (1) Bid placement (discovery phase) should immediately return 3-5 matching properties with photos and pricing, not just acknowledgment. (2) Providing location details (search phase) should trigger real-time map visualization showing available properties in that area, not a promise to 'do homework.' (3) Sharing schedule requirements should display price estimates for that pattern ('Most Wednesday-Saturday guests in your area pay $90-120/night'), providing social proof validation. (4) Each piece of information the guest provides should unlock a piece of information they receive, maintaining equal exchange. The pattern is: guest commits → platform reciprocates → guest commits further → platform reciprocates more. This builds a trust ladder where each step is validated before climbing to the next.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'I noticed that you registered on our website and you placed a bid. So that's your, you should be familiar with us, aren't you?' ... Guest: 'I see. Okay.' Agent: 'Okay, Zella, thank you so much for your time. I hope I would be able to get some stuff for you.'
evidence.insight: The agent acknowledges the guest's prior commitment (bid) to create consistency pressure, but provides nothing concrete in return. The call ends with 'I hope I would be able to get some stuff' rather than 'Here are three properties that match your needs.' This violates reciprocal exchange.

evidence.quote: For the salesperson, the strategy is to obtain a large purchase by starting with a small one. Almost any small sale will do, because the purpose of that small transaction is not profit. It is commitment. Further purchases, even much larger ones, are expected to flow naturally from the commitment.
evidence.insight: The bid is the 'small sale' that creates initial commitment. But unlike the successful sales pattern Cialdini describes, Split Lease doesn't follow through with the 'further purchases.' The guest makes the small commitment but doesn't receive the progression to larger value that would justify escalating investment.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'how long a walk would you accept? You saw 30 minutes... I'm trying to define an acceptable area so I can give you the best options.' Guest provides detailed location requirements (125th, 145th, St. Nicholas Park, shuttle access). Agent: 'I do have, uh, some vacations available.'
evidence.insight: Guest commits to specific location parameters, but agent provides only vague confirmation of 'some vacations available' without showing a single property. The commitment chain breaks here because the reciprocal value (actual listings) never materializes.

evidence.quote: Once we have made a choice or taken a stand, we will encounter personal and interpersonal pressures to behave consistently with that commitment. Those pressures will cause us to respond in ways that justify our earlier decision.
evidence.insight: This consistency pressure works only when the commitment leads somewhere. The guest can't justify her bid and call participation if they don't produce tangible results. Without seeing actual listings, there's nothing to be consistent WITH—the commitment has no object.

elements.user_goal: Each time I provide information or take a step forward, I want to receive something concrete that validates my effort and shows me I'm making progress toward finding housing.
elements.company_goal: Convert initial micro-commitments (bid, registration) into sustained engagement by providing immediate reciprocal value at each step, building a trust ladder that naturally progresses to proposal submission and booking.
elements.time_budget: Each commitment-reciprocation cycle should complete in under 30 seconds. Guest commits (provides location) → platform reciprocates (shows matching properties) in real-time, not days later via email.
anti_goals: DO NOT collect guest information for future use without providing immediate value. Each data point collected must unlock a corresponding insight or option for the guest.
DO NOT end any interaction with 'we'll be in touch' or 'I'll do some homework.' End with concrete next steps the guest can take immediately.
DO NOT treat the bid as the final commitment. It's the FIRST commitment in a chain that must be carefully reinforced with reciprocal value.
DO NOT make the guest wait days for information that could be shown immediately (available properties, price ranges, similar guests' successful matches).
elements.success_metric: Commitment progression rate: percentage of guests who complete Step N that also begin Step N+1 within the same session. Target: 80% from bid to search, 70% from search to listing evaluation, 60% from evaluation to proposal creation.

elements.title: Social Proof at Every Uncertainty Point
elements.problem: Zella's call contains zero social proof across all journey phases. Not once does the agent reference: other guests with similar needs, successful matches in the CCNY area, typical pricing for Wednesday-Saturday schedules, reviews of properties or hosts, testimonials from current split-lease residents, or any evidence that others have successfully completed this journey. The guest navigates entirely on trust in the agent. Cialdini's research shows that uncertainty is the condition under which social proof becomes most powerful—people rely on others' actions to validate decisions when they're unsure. The split-lease model is inherently uncertain (novel housing arrangement, complex matching, unfamiliar platform), making this the EXACT context where social proof is essential. Its complete absence creates a critical gap, especially when combined with complexity revelations (multi-week matching timeline, dual approval requirement with co-tenant, landlord economics affecting pricing) that increase uncertainty without providing confidence-building evidence.
elements.solution: Embed social proof at every point where the guest faces uncertainty about whether to continue, what to expect, or what constitutes normal/successful behavior. (1) Discovery phase: 'Join 1,200+ professionals who found flexible housing in NYC through Split Lease' + real guest photos/names/stories. (2) Search phase: Show how many guests searched in this area this month, what price ranges they accepted, how quickly they found matches. 'Most Wednesday-Saturday guests in your area find housing within 5-7 days.' (3) Listing evaluation: Display reviews from prior guests who stayed in this property + host response rate + acceptance rate for proposals on similar properties. (4) Proposal creation: 'Guests who included a personal message received responses 40% faster' + example successful proposals from similar guests. (5) Negotiation: Show typical price negotiation ranges for this property type/area. 'Similar guests settled at $95-110/night.' (6) Acceptance: Testimonials from guests who successfully matched with co-tenants, especially highlighting initial concerns and how they were resolved. (7) Move-in: Videos/photos of other guests' first day, what to expect, what to bring. (8) Active lease: Community forum where current split-lease residents share tips, coordinate with co-tenants, troubleshoot issues. The pattern is: uncertainty triggers social proof that reduces uncertainty and enables next step.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'I do have, uh, some vacations available. I just need, uh, to match you with, uh, people who will have a complimentary schedule... So now it will take me probably a couple of weeks to locate the mentioned individual, introduce you to that individual, because there's a way we operate when two users meet, to make sure that they're happy with each other.'
evidence.insight: The agent describes a complex, multi-week, multi-party process without providing any evidence that this process has worked for others. The guest must accept this on faith alone. One simple addition would transform uncertainty into confidence: 'Last month, I matched three other guests in Harlem using this same process, and all three are happily settled in their apartments now.'

evidence.quote: The tendency to see an action as more appropriate when others are doing it normally works quite well. As a rule, we will make fewer mistakes by acting in accord with social evidence than contrary to it. Usually, when a lot of people are doing something, it is the right thing to do.
evidence.insight: The guest has no social evidence to act in accord with. She doesn't know if 'a lot of people' are using Split Lease successfully, if her requirements are typical or unusual, if the multi-week timeline is standard or concerning. Without this evidence, she can't determine if continuing is 'the right thing to do.'

evidence.quote: Apparently the principle of social proof works best when the proof is provided by the actions of a lot of other people.
evidence.insight: Not just one testimonial, but multiple similar examples create the strongest social proof. Split Lease should show Zella that many guests with Wednesday-Saturday schedules in the CCNY area have found housing, not rely on one agent's promise to find her one match.

evidence.quote: CAUSE OF DEATH: UNCERTAIN(TY). In the process of examining the reactions of other people to resolve our uncertainty, however, we are likely to overlook a subtle but important fact. Those people are probably examining the social evidence, too. Especially in an ambiguous situation, the tendency for everyone to be looking to see what everyone else is doing can lead to a fascinating phenomenon.
evidence.insight: The split-lease housing model is highly ambiguous—most people have never shared a property on alternating schedules. This ambiguity creates maximum need for social proof. The guest NEEDS to see others successfully doing this before she'll commit.

evidence.quote: In general, then, your best strategy when in need of emergency help is to reduce the uncertainties of those around you concerning your condition and their responsibilities. Be as precise as possible about your need for aid.
evidence.insight: While this refers to emergency situations, the principle applies: uncertainty paralyzes action. The platform must reduce uncertainty about what happens next, what's normal, what success looks like—and social proof is the most efficient way to do this.

evidence.quote: Still another fascinating prediction flows from Phillips's idea. If the increase in wrecks following suicide stories truly represents a set of copycat deaths, then the imitators should be most likely to copy the suicides of people who are similar to them. The principle of social proof states that we use information about how others have behaved to help us determine proper conduct for ourselves. But as the dropped-wallet experiment showed, we are most influenced in this fashion by the actions of others like us.
evidence.insight: Social proof is most powerful when it comes from similar others. Zella needs to see evidence from other CCNY professionals, other Wednesday-Saturday guests, other people with her budget—not generic testimonials from random users.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'you identified $94 minimum, uh, that's what you're willing to pay, but what would be your budget?... when we are doing this pairing, we need to get to the full time lease for the landlord. So let's say if you need two nights and somebody needs five nights, that's the best case scenario, but sometimes somebody needs only four nights. In that case, we would have to go a little higher per night.'
evidence.insight: The agent explains complex landlord economics without providing social proof of actual outcomes. What the guest needs to hear: 'Most Wednesday-Saturday guests in your area ended up paying $100-115/night, depending on whether we found a perfect schedule match or needed to go slightly higher to make the landlord's numbers work.' Concrete evidence from similar guests would validate that this complexity is manageable and the outcomes are predictable.

elements.user_goal: At each decision point, see evidence that people like me have successfully done this before and that the path I'm considering is validated by others' positive experiences.
elements.company_goal: Convert platform uncertainty into confidence by showing guests that the novel split-lease model works in practice, that their requirements are achievable, and that similar guests have successfully completed the journey.
elements.time_budget: Social proof should be immediately visible at each phase transition—no more than 2 seconds to see relevant testimonials, statistics, or similar users' outcomes when entering a new phase.
anti_goals: DO NOT use generic testimonials ('Great platform! 5 stars!'). Social proof must be specific to the guest's context (location, schedule pattern, budget range, move-in timeline).
DO NOT hide social proof in separate pages or FAQs. It must be embedded at the exact moment of uncertainty.
DO NOT rely on aggregate statistics that feel distant ('10,000 successful bookings nationwide'). Show local, recent, similar examples ('4 guests found CCNY-area housing this month').
DO NOT manufacture or exaggerate social proof. Authenticity is critical—guests can detect fake testimonials and it destroys trust permanently.
elements.success_metric: Phase continuation rate correlation with social proof visibility: compare continuation rates for guests who view social proof elements vs. those who don't. Target: 25%+ higher continuation when social proof is viewed. Secondary: track which types of social proof (testimonials, statistics, similar users, reviews) drive highest continuation.

elements.title: Active Role Progression to Combat Commitment Decay
elements.problem: Zella's call ends with the agent promising 'I'll be in touch' and the guest waiting passively for contact. This creates a commitment decay window where the guest has no active role and her investment in the process dissipates over time. The agent says matching will take 'a couple of weeks,' during which the guest will likely pursue parallel housing options (traditional rentals, other platforms), reducing exclusive commitment to Split Lease. Cialdini's research shows that active commitments (writing, signing, choosing) are far more powerful than passive agreement. Throughout the call, the guest answered questions and provided information—passive activities that don't create strong commitment. She never took an active step like browsing available listings, creating a proposal, or setting search preferences on the platform. The only active step was the initial bid, which is now days in the past. The call should end with a clear active next step for the guest to maintain commitment momentum, but instead it creates a passive waiting period.
elements.solution: Convert passive waiting into active participation at every phase where the guest might otherwise disengage. (1) End discovery phase with active step: 'Create your search profile' where the guest sets location, dates, budget as interactive map exploration, not information provision to an agent. (2) Search phase: Guest actively browses listings with filters they control, favoriting properties, comparing options—continuous active engagement rather than waiting for agent to show options. (3) Listing evaluation: Guest actively creates a proposal with personalized message, schedule selection, price offer—this is a written commitment that Cialdini's research shows creates strong consistency pressure. (4) Negotiation: If host counters, guest actively responds (accept, counter-counter, decline with feedback) rather than waiting for agent to negotiate. (5) Acceptance: Guest actively confirms move-in logistics, adds move-in date to calendar, uploads ID for verification. The pattern is: never leave the guest waiting. Every phase transition should require an active step from the guest, even if small. This maintains commitment momentum and prevents the decay that occurs during passive waiting periods.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'I'll be in touch. I'm going to send you an introductory email with all my contact info. So feel free to contact me if you have any questions. Thank you. Bye.'
evidence.insight: Agent-driven next step ('I'll be in touch') rather than guest-driven action ('Here's how you browse available properties and create your first proposal'). This creates a commitment vacuum where the guest has no active role and commitment begins to decay immediately.

evidence.quote: If I can get you to make a commitment (that is, to take a stand, to go on record), I will have set the stage for your automatic and ill-considered consistency with that earlier commitment. Once a stand is taken, there is a natural tendency to behave in ways that are stubbornly consistent with the stand.
evidence.insight: The guest has not 'taken a stand' or 'gone on record' beyond the initial bid. She needs to actively create a proposal, write a personal message to a host, choose a specific property—these active commitments create the consistency pressure that makes follow-through more likely.

evidence.quote: Once we have made up our minds about an issue, stubborn consistency allows us a very appealing luxury: We really don't have to think hard about the issue anymore... Instead, all we have to do when confronted with the issue is to turn on our consistency tape, whirr, and we know just what to believe, say, or do.
evidence.insight: The guest hasn't 'made up her mind' in a way that activates consistency pressure. She's interested and exploring, but hasn't committed to a specific property or terms. The proposal creation step is where she commits to specifics, which then creates pressure to follow through even when obstacles arise.

evidence.quote: For the salesperson, the strategy is to obtain a large purchase by starting with a small one. Almost any small sale will do, because the purpose of that small transaction is not profit. It is commitment. Further purchases, even much larger ones, are expected to flow naturally from the commitment.
evidence.insight: The 'small sale' pattern requires continuous active steps, each building on the last. The guest placed a bid (small sale), but there's no next active step to build on it. She needs to actively browse (next small sale), then favorite a listing (next), then create a proposal (next), building an escalating ladder of active commitments.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'In that case, we would have to go a little higher per night to make it work for the landlord. So what would be your budget? Per night. What would be not to exceed?' Guest: 'I see. Okay.'
evidence.insight: The guest provides a vague acknowledgment ('I see. Okay.') rather than an active commitment to a specific budget. This is passive agreement, not active commitment. The platform should require her to set a maximum budget with a slider or input, creating an active commitment that then constrains her search and creates consistency pressure to accept offers within that range.

evidence.quote: If Sara has erred in her choice of Tim, how long could she go without clearly recognizing it, without having a massive heart of hearts attack? There is no telling. One thing is certain, however: As time passes, the various alternatives to Tim are disappearing. She had better determine soon whether she is making a mistake.
evidence.insight: The multi-week passive waiting period allows alternatives to Split Lease to solidify. If Zella finds a traditional rental during the 'couple of weeks' it takes to match her, Split Lease becomes the alternative that disappears. Active engagement during this period (browsing listings, creating proposals, messaging hosts) keeps Split Lease as her primary path rather than her backup option.

elements.user_goal: Always have a clear next action I can take immediately to move closer to finding housing, rather than waiting for someone to contact me with the next step.
elements.company_goal: Maintain commitment momentum by requiring continuous active participation from guests, preventing the commitment decay that occurs during passive waiting periods and reducing abandonment to parallel housing options.
elements.time_budget: No passive waiting period should exceed 24 hours. If a process requires days (matching, host response), provide active interim steps (browse other properties, refine search criteria, join community forum) to maintain engagement.
anti_goals: DO NOT end any interaction with 'we'll contact you' or 'check back later.' End with a specific action the guest can take immediately.
DO NOT make the platform require agent intervention for standard tasks (browsing, proposing, accepting). Reserve human contact for complex negotiations or problem resolution.

DO NOT allow guests to submit a proposal and then wait passively for host response. Provide active interim steps: view similar properties, get acceptance rate estimates, see how other guests improved their proposals.

DO NOT hide the guest's prior active commitments. Make them visible throughout the journey to reinforce consistency pressure ('You favorited 3 properties in this area, created 1 proposal, and set your maximum budget at $120/night').
elements.success_metric: Active engagement rate: percentage of guests who take at least one active step (browse, favorite, propose, message) within 24 hours of each prior step. Target: 70%+ for first 3 steps, 60%+ for subsequent steps. Secondary: time-to-booking correlation with number of active steps taken (hypothesis: more active steps = faster booking).

elements.title: Complexity Revelation Paired with Confidence Building
elements.problem: The agent progressively reveals complexity throughout the call without providing corresponding confidence-building elements. Revelations include: (1) Matching requirement—guest must be paired with another user with complementary schedule (4:11-4:26). (2) Multi-week timeline—'it will take me probably a couple of weeks to locate the mentioned individual' (4:26-4:45). (3) Mutual approval process—both parties must approve each other even though they won't overlap (4:45-4:48). (4) Landlord economics affecting pricing—guest's price depends on whether matching finds 2+5 nights or 2+4 nights, creating price unpredictability (5:55-6:26). Each revelation adds friction and uncertainty without corresponding evidence that this complexity is manageable or leads to successful outcomes. Cialdini's research shows that consistency pressure helps people rationalize difficult choices AFTER commitment, but these revelations occur BEFORE the guest has committed to a specific property or terms. Without social proof that others successfully navigated this complexity, each revelation increases dropout likelihood rather than strengthening resolve.
elements.solution: Pair every complexity revelation with immediate confidence-building evidence that validates the path forward. (1) When revealing matching requirement, immediately show: 'We've successfully matched 500+ guests with complementary schedules in the past 6 months. 94% of matches resulted in completed bookings.' + testimonials from matched guests. (2) When revealing timeline, immediately show: 'Average matching time for Wednesday-Saturday guests in your area: 5-7 days' with distribution graph showing most matches happen faster than 'a couple of weeks.' (3) When revealing mutual approval requirement, immediately show: 'Guest-to-guest approval rate: 89%' + examples of successful approval conversations + what makes a good match. (4) When revealing pricing complexity, immediately show: 'Most Wednesday-Saturday guests in your area pay $100-115/night regardless of matching configuration' with real examples and price range visualization. The pattern is: complexity + confidence = manageable challenge. Complexity alone = overwhelming obstacle. Never reveal complexity without simultaneously providing evidence that it's been successfully managed by others.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'I do have, uh, some vacations available. I just need, uh, to match you with, uh, people who will have a complimentary schedule. I don't know if you checked us out a little bit in depth and understand how split lease operates. We usually match two, uh, people with complimentary schedules... So now it will take me probably a couple of weeks to locate the mentioned individual, introduce you to that individual, because there's a way we operate when two users meet, to make sure that they're happy with each other.'
evidence.insight: Three complexity revelations in rapid succession (matching requirement, multi-week timeline, mutual approval) without any confidence-building evidence. The guest learns what's hard about this process but not what makes it succeed. One simple addition would transform this: 'I just matched three guests last week using this same process, and all of them found it easier than they expected. Would you like to hear how it worked for them?'

evidence.quote: Once we have made a choice or taken a stand, we will encounter personal and interpersonal pressures to behave consistently with that commitment. Those pressures will cause us to respond in ways that justify our earlier decision... They simply convinced themselves that they had made the right choice and, no doubt, felt better about it all.
evidence.insight: Consistency pressure helps people justify difficult choices AFTER commitment. But Zella hasn't committed to a specific property yet. She's learning about complexity before commitment, which creates doubt rather than justification. The complexity needs to be paired with social proof so she can commit WITH confidence, then consistency pressure will help her navigate obstacles.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'when we are doing this pairing, we need to get to the full time lease for the landlord. So let's say if you need two nights and somebody needs five nights, that's the best case scenario, but sometimes somebody needs only four nights. In that case, we would have to go a little higher per night to make it work for the landlord. So what would be your budget?'
evidence.insight: Pricing complexity revealed (outcome depends on matching success) without confidence-building context. The guest needs to hear: 'Here's the good news: in your area, whether we get perfect matching or not, Wednesday-Saturday guests typically end up between $100-115/night. So while the exact number depends on matching, you can plan for that range with confidence.' Frame complexity with predictable outcomes.

evidence.quote: The country--both physical and social--into which they were dropped must have seemed dreadfully uncertain. [Discussing Jonestown cult members in Guyana]
evidence.insight: Uncertainty creates vulnerability to bad decisions when no anchoring information exists. While Split Lease is obviously not Jonestown, the principle applies: when guests face uncertainty about a novel housing model without evidence of successful outcomes, they're vulnerable to either abandoning the process or making poor choices out of desperation (accepting bad terms because they're uncertain what good terms look like).

evidence.quote: The tendency to see an action as more appropriate when others are doing it normally works quite well. As a rule, we will make fewer mistakes by acting in accord with social evidence than contrary to it. Usually, when a lot of people are doing something, it is the right thing to do.
evidence.insight: Social proof specifically addresses uncertainty about whether an unfamiliar action is 'right.' When the agent reveals that guests must approve co-tenants they'll never meet, or that pricing depends on matching success—both unfamiliar concepts—the guest needs social evidence that 'a lot of people are doing this' successfully to determine it's 'the right thing to do.'

elements.user_goal: Understand what's complex about this process AND simultaneously see evidence that people like me have successfully navigated that complexity, so I feel challenged but capable rather than overwhelmed and uncertain.
elements.company_goal: Frame process complexity as a manageable challenge supported by evidence of successful outcomes, preventing complexity-driven dropout while maintaining transparency about how the platform works.
elements.time_budget: Confidence-building evidence must appear within 5 seconds of complexity revelation—ideally in the same sentence or visual frame. Don't make the guest sit with complexity alone before providing reassurance.
anti_goals: DO NOT hide complexity or pretend the process is simple when it's not. Transparency is essential for trust.
DO NOT reveal all complexity at once. Stage revelations to match journey progression, with each revelation paired to that phase's specific confidence needs.
DO NOT use vague reassurance ('Don't worry, it'll be fine'). Confidence must come from concrete evidence: statistics, testimonials, examples, predictable ranges.
DO NOT let the agent/platform know more about obstacles than the guest. Information asymmetry creates anxiety. Share what you know about typical outcomes, timelines, and success patterns.
elements.success_metric: Complexity comprehension without dropout: percentage of guests who view complexity explanations (matching process, pricing factors, approval requirements) and continue to next phase. Target: 75%+ continuation rate when complexity is paired with confidence evidence, vs. baseline without pairing.

elements.title: Platform Understanding Before Platform Encounter
elements.problem: Zella placed a bid on the website and registered on the platform, yet during the call she confuses 'Split Lease' with 'Straight Lease' (5:01-5:11) and needs the core concept explained from scratch. The agent must explain that Split Lease matches two people with complementary schedules (4:11-4:44), a fundamental concept that should have been clear before she submitted a bid. This reveals that the discovery phase failed to establish basic platform understanding. She could complete visible actions (registration, bid placement) without comprehending what the platform actually does or how it works. This creates a dangerous pattern: the guest makes early commitments (bid submission) based on incomplete understanding, then faces surprising complexity later (matching requirement, mutual approval, multi-week timeline) that she didn't anticipate. Cialdini's commitment research shows that small commitments create consistency pressure, but if those commitments were made under false assumptions, the consistency pressure weakens when reality becomes clear.
elements.solution: Require demonstrated platform understanding before allowing consequential commitments. (1) Discovery phase must clearly explain the split-lease model BEFORE allowing bid submission. Use interactive visualization: 'Here's how it works: You need Wednesday-Saturday. We match you with someone who needs Sunday-Tuesday. Together you fill the apartment, split the cost, and never overlap.' Require guest to interact with this explanation (click through steps, watch short video, answer simple comprehension question) before enabling bid submission. (2) Search phase must reinforce understanding with every listing: show the complementary schedule visually on each property card ('You use this apartment Wed-Sat. Your co-tenant uses it Sun-Tue.'). (3) Before proposal creation, require acknowledgment of key commitments: 'I understand I'll be matched with a co-tenant, we'll both need to approve each other, and matching typically takes 5-7 days.' This checkbox isn't legal CYA—it's commitment reinforcement through active acknowledgment. (4) Use consistent terminology everywhere. If the platform calls it 'split lease' in one place, 'shared tenancy' in another, and 'periodic rental' in a third, guests will be confused. Pick one term and use it religiously. The pattern is: comprehension gates commitment. Don't accept commitments from confused guests.

evidence.quote: Guest: 'I'm sorry, can you repeat your question? So you said you were with straight easy or straight lease? No, it's not straight lease. Split lease. S P L I T, yes. Split lease and I noticed that you registered on our website and you placed a bid. So that's your, you should be familiar with us, aren't you?'
evidence.insight: The guest registered AND placed a bid without even correctly remembering the platform name. This is a catastrophic comprehension failure. She made commitments (registration, bid) based on essentially zero understanding. The agent's 'you should be familiar with us, aren't you?' reveals the assumption that platform interaction creates understanding, but clearly it doesn't.

evidence.quote: Agent: 'I do have, uh, some vacations available. I just need, uh, to match you with, uh, people who will have a complimentary schedule. I don't know if you checked us out a little bit in depth and understand how split lease operates. We usually match two, uh, people with complimentary schedules.'
evidence.insight: The agent must explain the fundamental platform concept during the call, indicating it wasn't clear during discovery. The phrase 'I don't know if you checked us out a little bit in depth' is telling—it suggests platform understanding is optional and discovery phase didn't ensure it happened.

evidence.quote: If I can get you to make a commitment (that is, to take a stand, to go on record), I will have set the stage for your automatic and ill-considered consistency with that earlier commitment. Once a stand is taken, there is a natural tendency to behave in ways that are stubbornly consistent with the stand.
evidence.insight: The bid is an 'ill-considered consistency' trap if the guest doesn't understand what she's committing to. She'll feel pressure to continue because of the bid, but that pressure is built on a false foundation. When she learns the reality (matching, multi-week timeline, mutual approval), the consistency pressure collapses because the commitment was made under different assumptions.

evidence.quote: Guest: 'So I'm looking to, because I work at CCNY I'm looking to be close to that area. So where I could possibly walk, how close as your place to CCNY?' Agent: 'Uh, well, uh, Zella, I work for split lease.'
evidence.insight: The guest thinks she's speaking to a host with a specific property ('how close as YOUR place'), not understanding that Split Lease is a platform connecting multiple properties. This fundamental misunderstanding persists despite registration and bid placement, proving that those actions didn't establish basic platform comprehension.

evidence.quote: Once we have made a choice or taken a stand, we will encounter personal and interpersonal pressures to behave consistently with that commitment. Those pressures will cause us to respond in ways that justify our earlier decision.
evidence.insight: Consistency pressure works when the commitment and the outcome align. But if the guest committed to 'finding an apartment quickly' (her assumption when placing the bid) and later learns the reality is 'multi-week matching process with co-tenant approval,' the commitment and the reality don't align. She can't justify her earlier decision because it was based on incomplete information.

elements.user_goal: Understand clearly what Split Lease is, how it works, and what I'm committing to BEFORE I take any significant action like submitting a bid or providing personal information.
elements.company_goal: Ensure all guest commitments (bid, registration, proposal) are made with full comprehension of the platform model, preventing surprise-driven dropout when complexity is revealed and ensuring consistency pressure is built on accurate understanding.
elements.time_budget: Platform explanation should take 30-60 seconds maximum and must happen before first commitment action. Use progressive disclosure: brief explanation before bid (30 sec), more detail before proposal (60 sec), full depth before acceptance (as long as needed).
anti_goals: DO NOT allow bid submission or registration without demonstrable comprehension. A 5-second comprehension check ('Which statement is true? A) You rent the full apartment alone, B) You share with a co-tenant on different days, C) You visit properties then decide') prevents confused commitments.
DO NOT assume that platform interaction equals platform understanding. Guests can click buttons without comprehending concepts.

DO NOT use jargon or internal terminology in discovery phase. 'Split lease,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'complementary schedules' are meaningless to first-time visitors. Use plain language: 'You use the apartment Wed-Sat. Someone else uses it Sun-Tue. You split the cost and never overlap.'
DO NOT bury the explanation in FAQ or About pages. It must be unavoidable in the primary flow before commitment actions.
elements.success_metric: Comprehension-to-commitment accuracy: percentage of guests who can correctly explain the platform model after completing discovery phase. Target: 90%+ can correctly identify that they'll be matched with a co-tenant on different days. Secondary: reduction in dropout rate during complexity revelation phases (if comprehension is established early, later complexity should be less surprising).
